alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for assets bought, sold or given
overview: Tax and reporting rules for assets bought, sold or given
title: Expenses and benefits: assets bought, sold or given

table.body:
As an employer buying, selling or giving assets to your employees, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.

##What's included

Assets can include:

- computers
- televisions
- cars
- bicycles

^If you let your employee use an asset that you own, you should see the guide for [assets made available](/expenses-and-benefits-assets-made-available-to-an-employee "assets made available").^
table.title: Overview

table.body:
What you have to deduct, pay and report to HMRC depends on how much your employee earns, and what you did with the asset, eg whether you bought it, sold it or gave it away. 

##Selling or giving away an asset

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to pay
- | -
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year | Report on form P9D, section A(2) | Nothing
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year | Report on form P11D, section A | Class 1A National Insurance on the value of the benefit
Directors | Report on form P11D, section A | Class 1A National Insurance on the value of the benefit

##Buying an asset

If you buy an asset from an employee for more than its market value, the premium you’ve paid counts as earnings, so:

- add it to your employee’s other earnings
- deduct and pay PAYE tax and Class 1 National Insurance through payroll


*[HMRC]: HM Revenues & Customs
*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
table.title: What to report and pay

table.body:
##Give or sell a new asset to an employee

If your employee earns [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year, the value is:

- how much the asset is worth second-hand when you transfer it

If your employee earns [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year, or if they're a director, the value is the higher of:

- how much the asset is worth second-hand when you transfer it
- how much you bought the asset for

##Give or sell a used or depreciated asset (not previously made available as a benefit)

The value is how much the asset is worth second-hand when you transfer it.

##Give or sell a used asset that you’ve previously made available as a benefit

If your employee earns [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year, the value is:

- how much the asset is worth second-hand when you transfer it

If your employee earns [at a rate](/employer-reporting-expenses-and-benefits/reporting-and-paying "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year, or if they're a director, the value is the higher of:

- how much the asset is worth second-hand when you transfer it
- how much the asset is worth when you first provided it as a benefit, minus any amount that was subject to tax or National Insurance while you were providing it as a benefit

[See an example](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/eim21651.htm "Transfer of an asset previously available for use by a director or employee: example"){:rel="external"} of how this works.

###Exceptions for assets previously available as a benefit

The value is calculated differently if you give or sell the following assets to a director, or an employee earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more:

- cars
- vans
- bicycles or cyclists’ safety equipment
- living accommodation
- computer equipment that you made available for private use when a limited exemption for computers was in force (until 6 April 2006)

The value to use is how much the asset is worth second-hand when you transfer it.

##Buy an asset from an employee

The value to use is the amount you pay over the asset’s market value.
